channel.title: Strip down Microsoft XP/Vista for ultimate speed!
channel.description:
Strip down Microsoft XP/Vista for ultimate speed! nLite for XP - www.nliteos.com - [url=http://www.nliteos.com/files/scrn1.png]Screenshot[/url] - [url=http://www.teamtutorials.com/windows-tutorials/how-to-make-a-custom-windows-install-w-nlite]Tutorial[/url] vLite for Vista - www.vlite.net - [url=http://www.vlite.net/img/shots/ss1.png]Screenshot[/url] - [url=http://www.tutorialstuff.com/tutorial_display.php?id=432]Tutorial[/url] I could have made a tutorial for this but it would have been a pain in the ass! Any way, the program is called nLite for XP and vLite for Vista. I'll explain the programs now. What each program does is, extract all the files off your Windows Installation CD (sorry but this is required) then let's you pick which things you want to remove and which you want to keep. Finally, at the very end of the installation it will make an ISO file which you can then put on a CD to install your Windows OS! Some of the most useful things about this is that it has the potential to make Windows XP/Vista EXTREMELY fast by removing the shit installed when you first install the OS. It can also apply security patches, add-ons, and etc into the ISO file. That means say you wanted to install Service Pack 2, you can attach it on and it will install SP2 when it finishes installing XP. You can also have it install programs like [url=http://www.ccleaner.com]CCleaner[/url] or any programs from [url=http://www.winaddons.com]Win Addons[/url]! Small tip: When using nLite/vLite, on the first or second (not sure) it will ask you to locate your windows installation. This is when you create a folder on your desktop and call it something like Fast Windows or something, then type the location of that folder, and then it will take all the files off your Windows XP/Vista CD and put them in that file so they may be changed.
Have you ever wanted to remove Windows components like Media Player, Internet Explorer, Outlook Express, MSN Explorer, Messenger... How about not even to install them with Windows ? nLite is a tool for permanent Windows components removal and pre-installation Windows configuration. After removal there is an option to make bootable image ready for burning on cd or testing in virtual machines. With nLite you will be able to have Windows installation which on install does not include, or even contain on cd, the unwanted components. Features * Service Pack Integration * Component Removal * Unattended Setup * Driver Integration * * Hotfixes Integration ** * Tweaks * Services Configuration * Patches *** * Bootable ISO creation * - Textmode (CD Boot) and normal PnP ** - hotfixes with white icons, *KB*.exe, including update packs and Internet Explorer 7 ***- supports generic SFC, Uxtheme, TcpIp and Usb Polling patching. nLite supports Windows 2000, XP x86/x64 and 2003 x86/x64 in all languages. It needs .NET Framework 2.0 in order to run... Check if you have it already, maybe on some of your CDs before downloading if your connection is slow. You may report on the forum any bugs or annoyances found. And remember it is freeware, meaning that only fuel is a good word or a donation.
It's one fantastic program! If you have ever heard of TinyXP, a popular Windows OS which has been stripped down and torrented, which had used nLite. Another fantastic feature is the "Unattended Setup" where you can setup all the information before compiling the ISO file which is just AWESOME! This way you don't have to stare at the computer screen while installing Windows and then saying Yes, Ok, Blah blah blah RRRRRAHHHHH!!! Also, if you really compact windows, you can make it so that it only runs around 50 or 60 MB of RAM on startup whereas normal people run around 250 - 300 MB or more! I tested this on my Pentium 3 which is about 6 or 7 years old now and XP used to run real slow, but now it's as if we have Windows 98 on it all over again. This stripping down the OS is also great to put on a Virtual Machine. There are some people who have put on 5 - 10 versions of Windows right on their VMs. It's Siiiick! Hope you like it! :) ~Ron All thanks to Boreas for telling me of TinyXP which led me to nLite!

item.title: Strip down Microsoft XP/Vista for ultimate speed!
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

MybJames:

Ron, i think that korn was suprised when his hard disk did not lose all files.

I think you’re right, but I thought I made it very clear that you need the Installation CD of XP/Vista and all it will do is take an image of that CD and then change its contents and create a new image file which you can use to install. I guess I didn’t make it clear enough if what you’re saying is true.

[quote=“Freddy1990, post:30, topic:98353”]Man ur slow, I’ve been using nLite for a year or 2, lol
I’m not always as satisfied of the results though…[/quote]
If I’m so slow and you’re so fast, please enlighten the community with other gems of programs you’re hording away from us.

Read full topic

item.title: Strip down Microsoft XP/Vista for ultimate speed!
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

Rictoo:

nLite is also what is used to make small XP install disks like TinyXP. So if you want to make an install disk to sell, just use nLite

If you read the first post, you would have seen that I have already included that.

KoRnRoOsTeR:

Hey Ron i have vista right and i finnally got some blank DVD disks but i want to keep some programs that my computer needs i think like ATI Catalyst Control Center, and Intel Vivv Software. Will this effect my computer?

Hmm. Well I just googled ATI Catalyst Control Center and off this website…
http://ati.amd.com/products/catalystcontrolcenter/index.html
you can download that drive and if you google some more I’m sure you will be able to download the Intel Vivv Software.

Any other questions? Consult the vLite forum.
http://www.msfn.org/board/index.php?showforum=153

On another note, remember that vLite is still in beta. If you are happy with your computer and it’s already pretty fast, don’t worry about it. Just make sure to turn off the shit services and your computer should be even faster!

Turn off Shitty Vista Services

~Ron

Read full topic

item.title: Strip down Microsoft XP/Vista for ultimate speed!
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

KoRnRoOsTeR:

ok what if i need help could u give me some?? lol sorry but i bearly got this computer and i dont want to mess it up. ok i think im going to do it but, i need to but the cd in my computer right? or the files are already on my HardDrive.

You need the Windows XP/Vista installation disk in order to create your own modified Windows install disk. I hope you know that you can’t change your existing installation of Windows. You can only create your own install disk with various components removed/added. So if you do use this, remember you will have to install Windows again.

and sorry KoRnRoOsTeR, but I really can’t help with vLite since I have only used nLite. Try this vLite tutorial.
http://www.tutorialstuff.com/tutorial_display.php?id=432

Read full topic

item.source: Strip down Microsoft XP/Vista for ultimate speed!

item.title: Strip down Microsoft XP/Vista for ultimate speed!
item.dc:creator: @KoRnRoOsTeR KoRnRoOsTeR
item.description:
@KoRnRoOsTeR wrote:

[quote=“Ron, post:11, topic:98353”][quote author=KoRnRoOsTeR link=topic=141420.msg1357178#msg1357178 date=1179810711]
Do you boot from this or install it on windows?
[/quote]

You can use the .ISO file to make a bootable Live CD of the Windows Installation for testing purposes and you can use the .ISO file to install Windows. So, the answer to your question: Both.

ok… what about backing up your drivers and stuff? i formatted on xp and lost all my drivers and now my display on xp looks like shit.

You can always download drivers from www.microsoft.com. If the drivers have nothing to do with Microsoft and have to do something with 3rd party software like printer software, then go to that company’s website and download drivers from there.

In nLite you can choose to include the preinstalled drivers or leave them out. This software let’s you take out and leave in whatever you like, so as long as you know what you’re doing, you will be fine.[/quote]

ok what if i need help could u give me some?? lol sorry but i bearly got this computer and i dont want to mess it up. ok i think im going to do it but, i need to but the cd in my computer right? or the files are already on my HardDrive.

Read full topic
item.source: Strip down Microsoft XP/Vista for ultimate speed!

item.title: Strip down Microsoft XP/Vista for ultimate speed!
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

KoRnRoOsTeR:

Do you boot from this or install it on windows?

You can use the .ISO file to make a bootable Live CD of the Windows Installation for testing purposes and you can use the .ISO file to install Windows. So, the answer to your question: Both.

KoRnRoOsTeR:

ok… what about backing up your drivers and stuff? i formatted on xp and lost all my drivers and now my display on xp looks like shit.

You can always download drivers from www.microsoft.com. If the drivers have nothing to do with Microsoft and have to do something with 3rd party software like printer software, then go to that company’s website and download drivers from there.

In nLite you can choose to include the preinstalled drivers or leave them out. This software let’s you take out and leave in whatever you like, so as long as you know what you’re doing, you will be fine.

Read full topic
